content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												IMO, one of the better COD available to PC. Had a rough launch but Treyarch seems to be the only activision COD developer who cares about PC gaming; rolling out bug fixes quickly and including FOV slider.This has true Dedicated server support and support of unranked modded servers. The community has very much diminished, and most of the lower latency NA servers are mostly Nuketown forever game types with almost no servers hosting DLC.Buying DLC for this is only justifiable if you desire to play the Zombies game mode; which is an absolute blast, especially with friends; going for those higher levels and finding all the easter eggs.My favorite part of this COD is the gunplay. Trades in gunfights tend to go to the more skilled player rather than the player who sees the other first (like we see in newer COD titles).In summary:Pros:Twitch Shooter with skill oriented gun playTrue Dedicated Servers with Mod Support on unranked ServersZombies gametype with tons of replayCons:90 FPS Cap (Old Quake engine bugs when running over 120 FPS)Lack of Eyefinity or Surround multi Display support (Flawless Widescreen or Widescreen fixer solves this)Small CommunityNuketown everywhereNo point of buying DLC unless you like the zombies game type

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												With all the uncertainties surrounding the Activision/Infinity Ward debacle that took place back in March 2010, many pondered an inevitable fall from grace for the Call of Duty franchise. With Medal of Honor's impending preempt release, that speculation was still debatable. However, hardly anyone ever considered the opposite. Except for maybe those who were hard at work behind the doors at Treyarch. They were given an opportunity to prove to the naysayers of the Infinity Ward fan club that they could bring the franchise to bigger and better heights. Even with that skepticism, the team at Treyarch knew what was at stake and have made their point very clear.Call of Duty: Black Ops took a lot of risks by stepping away from the norm, particularly in terms of storytelling. Players primarily take the role of Alex Mason, a man who is being held captive and interrogated for information concerning the Ascension Group. A seemingly random sequence of numbers is being broadcast at an unknown location, and his captors believe he has the answers to unravel their mystery. It's hard to speak too much on the plot's topic without giving away any spoilers, but I will say this; their new formula was a huge success.The story still has plenty of the blockbuster elements that the franchise is known for, but manages to portray itself in a much more intelligent light. It's not just the typical action for action's sake type of game. The story has a well-written narrative that conspiracy buffs will surely love. Not only that, but the main character has a more vocal presence than any previous Call of Duty. The developers even decided to take a slightly more cinematic approach with the addition of a few cutscenes, rather than having dialogue throughout loading screens to help with the pacing. They managed to keep a good balance between set piece moments as well, which are just as intense as ever. Some of the most brutal melee kills are executed during stealth segments, and I imagine that's why they included an option to turn off "graphic" content at the start of the game.The single player campaign wasn't the only bold evolution that took place, as the multiplayer component had its fair share of alterations. The most prominent is the new currency upgrade system. This new progression method allows players to earn "COD" points in addition to experience points during matches. Not only is this improvement leaps and bounds over the old, but it also gives players a level field by having all perks and attachments available for purchase at the start. Also, once you've unlocked the appropriate categories through ranking up, you can acquire any kill streak reward you wish or invest in an insane amount of customization options. Higher-tier weapons are still unlocked at certain ranks as well, but the advantages they once held are now an issue of the past.This new Combat Training simulator lets you practice Free-For-All or Team Deathmatch modes against AI opponents. This is a great way for new players to work their way into an online multiplayer setting at their own pace, and will be a perfect way for clans to map out and plan new attack strategies. If that wasn't enough, Treyarch even included an in-depth Combat Record to give a detailed look at how your multiplayer stats break down. It includes everything from kill/death ratio graphs, individual weapon stats, to heat maps that show the main spots of activity. The training mode can even be played cooperatively online or locally with split-screen through all fourteen multiplayer maps at your disposal.Although the campaign doesn't support co-op play, the now-famous zombie mode certainly does. Even though fighting off the walking dead can be fun alone, it's even better with up to four players and is as frantic as ever. There is even a random zombie surprise that appears after the credits roll once you finish the campaign. Call of Duty: Black Ops is certainly not without its faults. The game has some decent looking graphics but is hindered by poorly rendered two-dimensional textures. This becomes even more apparent when you play the game in stereoscopic 3D, which is fully supported if your TV is also capable of this functionality. The 3D aspect obviously grants a better depth of field, but feels more like an attached gimmick than anything else. Fast camera movements become easily blurred, and the overall presentation gets a huge downgrade when it's turned on.But aside from those minute missteps, Treyarch did an amazing of proving they can innovate within this franchise, and not be held back by their publisher's ongoing dispute. Their new vision for the Call of Duty series is definitely a bold step, but it's a step in the right direction. This game is jam-packed with content that is very well worth the price tag they're selling it for. The campaign is roughly a 7-8 hour ride, and a great one at that, and the multiplayer has a shelf life that will likely outlast the console it's played on.In all honesty, the multiplayer component is so well thought-out that it could have been released as a stand-alone experience. The new upgrade system, the statistic tracking, and the vast amount of customization is enough to keep players engrossed for hours; and that's not even part of the gameplay. The real fun is getting to play with all the new kill streak rewards. They range anywhere from the incredibly entertaining RC-XD remote car bomb to a pack of gruesome attack dogs, and all are as satisfying as ever. It'd be hard to argue that Black Ops is anything less than phenomenal. The campaign is thrilling from beginning to end, the competitive multiplayer is as addictive as ever, and there are plenty of zombies to be slaughtered for all the co-op junkies out there.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												With all my respect to COD games that were released before COD 4 and that have made the COD franchise that far, this is one of the most PC friendly (besides COD 4) and the best Call of Duty for PC (played all COD`s from COD 4 except WAW on PC), Dedicated Servers for best multiplayer experience, balanced weapons every weapon has different recoil type, variety of maps from big (Jungle) to small (Nuketown), mostly mature community (not like MW3 or MW2), unique singleplayer with an interesting excited story played in cold war, authentic soundtrack  that is much different from average military fps games, Zombies is also fun to play from time to time. The bad things, slightly framerate drops in multiplayer (dont worry, doesnt happen too much) but if its happen sometimes you want to kill someone at the same time its annoying. Chopper Gunner Killstreak in multiplayer is so overpowered and its worst thing that can happen to you, even with M.O.A.B i can deal with it in MW3 but not with CG in BO1. What i also dont like is, the massive action in singleplayer, they could have been lowered the action so you will not be bombarded with weapon noizes all the time and massive explosions also. Sure its cool and something that belongs to COD games but sometimes its too much.If the games age (2010) doesnt matter, buy this COD if you are planning to buy your first COD on PC.

content:
Posted: February 6
"MY NAME IS VIKTOR REZNOV"It's been 6 years since I played Black Ops for this first and my last time. During those years I've played all of the Call of Duty games repeatedly over and over again. I don't have exact count, but I can assume each game 4-5 times except Black Ops 1. Why? As far as I can remember, I just didn't want this game to be like others. So for 4 years I didn't play it because I didn't want to, but I can remember that last 2 years I didn't play it because I couldn't. However thank to those 6 years of Black Ops absence in my gaming life, I have recieved even better gaming experience these days than back in 2011 and one of the best gaming experiences during last years. This is how Call of Duty is supposed to look like, and this is how FPS game is supposed to look like. Storytelling is whole new level for entire Call of Duty universe and you cannot deny that. I love the way how even 2 seconds flashback in like 3rd mission gets explained in the end just by one sentence, without even showing that certain flashback to remind you.You can argue that story is not really that deep. Yes, I know that surely there are way way way more deeper stories than this one, but for mainstream game, for AAA game and for Call of Duty, this one is really deeper than usual. I am talking a lot about it but why not. For me it's more important than gameplay and whole interaction with the world.I also do know that this review is not objective at all, because my rating will be really high, and also every gamer have something that he loves in particular. Either it is era, persons, countries and of course events. And maybe that is why I admire Black Ops 1 - it has all what I love in particular. Also I do like that usual and standard feature called "Mission Select". I just love it when it is in game. It helps you with achievements, to get them faster, and also you can reply some significant missions without having to play it all over again. I also like the way they put music during the missions. Yeah, I'm talking about Creedence Clearwater Revival.Locations you'll visit are very-well picked. From wet jungles of Laos and 'Nam to cold Ural Mountains to hot cosmodrome in Baikonur. Notable real characters for me: Fidel Castro & JFK. Notable missions: EVERY. The variations of missions and nature of what you'll do is just absolutely awesome. I love every single objective you have to do and I love every single step you have to do. People complain about price point, but let me tell you this - cry about every other COD game that goes after BO1.That's it.  I know that my reviews for AAA games are usually not great at all and I do struggle with them, but that's the way it is and I'll try to improve it as much as I can.Things I won't comment either because I don't want to or I'll in future: Graphics, Downloadable Content, Zombies, Multiplayer.Bonus Point: Alex MasonRating: 10/10

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Now this game is a great game, even if it is old and because it has multiple modes I will make different sections for each one.Singleplayer:The Story in this game was very unique and catching. I enjoyed it alot more than any other story of any other Call of Duty. The Controls where easy and the voice acting was great! The only annoying thing was that the default fov is 65. But if you look around on the internet you will find a guide that helps you changing it into 90. The Most annoying thing by far was that for some reason it didn't read my save file proper and after restarting the game I had to restart also the story. But after all the problems have been fixed I could enjoy the singleplayer like no other. It was worth going through that as I really felt some of the characters growing to my heart!Zombiemode:The Zombiemode in this game is alot different from the second, it is harder and also in my opinion alot scarier than Number 2. If you happen to play on your own you can have 90 fov but as soon as you play online and/or with your friends it will stay on 65 fov. Which I find personally annoying. But it is still a good game mode to play in singleplayer mode. It is alot of fun.Multiplayer:Unlike other Call of Dutys this game has an actual Serverbrowser where you can search for a server of any kind to join. Most of them do not have any admins anymore but it is still alot of fun to play on them. In the Multiplayer mode you can change and keep your FOV from 65 up to 90. All in all this game is amazing, the graphics are still good looking and I had no problems running it on the highest setting. Although there is one thing I would like to mention. If you are german you will get the cut version because of Nazis and the Hackenkreuz. I do not know how much they cut out but I am pretty sure it must have been quiet a bit. I recommend you getting this game uncut from a key website. You will have the same fun as anybody else for a cheaper price!Which is one of my last points. This game has a great singleplayer, story and zombie mode. But for the fact on how old this game is and that hardly anybody still plays the multiplayer (compared to more newer cods anyways) I recommend to get this game on sale.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												I vividly remember the hype over Call of Duty: Black Ops. Black Ops was going to be the next best thing. It was going to be great, and fix all the problems in the previous Call of Duty games. I wasn’t a COD player at that time, and had a bit of a more balanced view of the release. I knew that Black Ops wasn’t going to be the impeccable masterpiece the COD community was hyping it to be. I believed that, like the games that had come before it, Black Ops was going to have its own fair share of problems too.I vividly remember the community backlash when the game came out and players finally realized this. Most of the prominent members of the COD community grumblingly played Black Ops because it was the popular thing to do--until they eventually abandoned it and looked back to previous games, waiting anxiously for Modern Warfare 3 to come a savior. The golden age of Call of Duty seemed to be over. Fortunately (or unfortunately to some) this is not where the story ends; for me, it was the beginning.I started to play Black Ops in its prime, a few months after it came out. It was my first real Call of Duty game (my only previous experience with the series was Call of Duty 2) and I was excited to play the game most people were playing. I discovered that the communities’ extreme reaction to Black Ops was a bit uncalled for.I originally braced myself for a pretty awful single player experience, but was pleasantly surprised at the story, plot, and characters. The single player is nothing revolutionary, but the characters are memorable (especially Woods) and the plot was compelling enough to make me sincerely want to see how it ended. I also found the missions, specifically the Vietnam missions, quite fun. Vorkuta is also highly memorable. In short, is a single player experience I could definitely see myself playing yet again.Co-op is almost equally as fun. Taking out endless waves of the zombified Nazis and other undead, aided by Perk-a-Colas, random mystery box guns, and Pack-a-Punched power weapons is a blast every time. Play with a group of dedicated friends, and let the good times swarm! I don’t like all the maps, but if you have people willing to play with you, then the expansion packs could be worth your money; with that many maps to choose from, I believe it would be difficult not to find at least one map that you all will enjoy playing together. Just a personal thought of mine though-- I wish that there were some kind of progress system in zombies--not just a "lets see how many waves we can get through in one game" approach. The amount of points earned in each match could be used as experience points to level up--more like the multiplayer experience. Just an idea, but this could have created a deeper gameplay experience. Of course, any Call of Duty player knows that the multiplayer is what makes or breaks an installment, no matter how good or bad the single player and/or co-op experiences are. For everything that Black Ops multiplayer does well, there are an equal number of points that flag for improvement. I think my favorite parts of the multiplayer are the emblems/playercards. Players have the ability to craft almost anything they want as a symbol for their playercard, and creative/ artistic players have the shapes to create some beautiful pieces of artwork! The contract system is a fun way to gamble for extra CODpoints to spend on your custom classes. They are completely optional, and you can choose ones that conform to your personal skill level, but the greatest rewards come with the highest challenge. Daring players may also gamble with their hard-earned CODpoints in wager matches, but hardly anyone plays these modes anymore. CODpoints are new to the franchise, and I found it nice to spend cash-like money on equipment that I wanted. While weapons still unlock at certain levels, perks, grenades, and other equipment are all yours to buy as soon as custom classes are unlocked at level 4. I find all of the weapons unique, easily recognizable, and fun to experiment with--almost characters in their own right. I don’t like to use all of them, and players could definitely debate whether some of them are balanced. Certain weapons seem to be the go-to choices, but I don’t personally don’t feel any of them are “over-powered”. All of them have their own checks and balances: The M60 can tear through players, but is quite inaccurate; the Skorpion is devastating at point blank range but damage falloff is incredibly sharp; and the Commando is the king of assualt rifles, but doesn't unlock until level 44. The list can go on, but I believe with all these safety measures put in place, every player should be able to find at least one weapon he can enjoy using.The maps are one of the biggest areas that need improvement. While I actually enjoy them all, Treyarch could do well to experiment with a different color pallet. When white, green, and brown are all the maps come in (the exception being Nuketown), these colors get old very quickly. The expansion pack maps are much more aesthetically exciting, but don’t expect to find too many servers that have them in the map rotation. If you really want to play them, gather some friends and start a custom game.A few other more minor things could use some tweaking. Hit markers were terrible when the game first came out, but have since been patched to the point where there are few issues with them, although I believe hitboxes tend to trail a tad too far behind the player. There are a couple of things that were never patched, however. Napalm strikes often have an invisible fire effect. Depending on the terrain over which the strike was laid down, there may be patches of earth left physically untouched by the fire, but players will still be killed if they run over these areas. Napalm and mortar strikes also have the bad habit of killing players in sturdy buildings when the strikes are directed on the roofs. I also wish that players weren’t allowed to make an “invisible” class. I don’t usually complain about weapons or equipment in this game (except Second Chance, which I hate with a passion) because I believe they all have the right to be used since the developers put them in the game, but it seems far too unbalanced to be allowed to run Ghost (Pro), Ninja (Pro), and a suppressor on both primary and secondary weapons. I do have to admit, though, I have only encountered a handful of players who use this setup.Overall, I find Black Ops a unique, but lukewarm experience. The weapons are striking and lively; the maps are not as exciting, but fun to play nonetheless. Contracts and CODpoints are interesting additions to the series, although some killstreaks can be frustrating to deal with. And both player emblems and custom classes can be beautiful or ugly, depending on the taste of the creator. All of the things done right mix with almost an equal blend of mistakes, creating an experience that is neither great nor bad. Ultimately though, I believe that COD players who approach Black Ops with an open mind, as the new branch of Call of Duty as it is, will find a lot of fun here. New players to the COD series may also enjoy Black Ops, although they should be prepared for a steep learning curve--this is still Call of Duty, and the gameplay is as fast and furious as it is deadly. Was Black Ops the next great thing to happen to Call of Duty? That would depend largely upon who you ask, but my answer is no. Does it deserve to go down in history as the game that ended COD’s golden age? Again, my answer is no. It may not continue the legacy of the games before it, but Black Ops is not an ending; rather it is the beginning of a new age of Call of Duty. And in my eyes, from what I have seen through my time with Black Ops, that age is looking surprisingly bright.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Call of Duty: Black Ops’ campaign mode has a genuinely interesting, psychological thriller style narrative and fun gameplay set pieces. I ended up finishing the campaign on ‘Veteran’ difficulty which changed my whole perspective of the game.It’s now my opinion that ‘Veteran’ difficulty is the best way to experience this campaign. It fits perfectly with the dark and gritty tone of the game’s design. Which caused me to become much more immersed in the action. The music is really cool too which also helped to pull me into the world.The ‘Zombie’ mode is, of course, also great here and most of these maps have become classics. I didn’t play too much of the Multiplayer but the maps look great. I’m always amazed with the high quality visuals and attention to detail in Call of Duty Multiplayer maps.This is an innovative and amazingly dark game which is loaded with replay value. The Call of Duty series has become completely mainstream now and receives a lot of criticism from gamers for being generic.  Black Ops is just as interesting and immersive as any other great game. It’s a total classic and I highly recommend that you go back and play through the campaign on ‘Veteran’ difficulty.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Campaign/Zombies ReviewQuite simply, this game has one of the best campaign plots I've ever seen. The 1960's, CIA Black Ops in Russia and the Vietnam War, conspiracies, and a diabolical political plot to topple nations... all taken seriously in a totally immersive and epic experience. The gameplay is varied, indoors and outdoors, from lush tropical jungles to intelligence headquarters buildings, in a number of different historical conflicts. No spoilers, but the whole story is about finding a hidden, classified truth that is as mindblowing as the warheads that threaten to destroy the world. This dynamic and interesting campaign is unmatched, certainly throughout the Call of Duty series, as well as all the games I've played. It may not be the newest game, but the plot is worth it, I guarantee.Although the plot and story elements alone are enough to warrant a purchase, it is as fun of an ADS FPS as I've ever played, with decent graphics, punchy weapons, and great levels. I've played through the entire game on Veteran Difficulty, the most challenging difficulty, and had an absolute blast. There's not an overwhelming amount of collectables, and they remain found after multiple playthroughs.The Zombies mode in this game is also great, probably better than Black Ops 2. It's not overly complicated like its sequel, and is just solid and hardy. I'm terrible at Zombies and still loved it. In one level you actually get to play as John F. Kennedy fighting zombies in the US Pentagon. Awesome? Awesome.One of my favorites! This isn't a review for the multiplayer, but it is also spectacular and they come together when you get black ops.

Steam price is totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It's a 6 years old game and Activision should stop raising this game's price because the third game has released. Yes, i see what you did there, Activision, you doubled the price last year. <end of TL;DR>I started playing CoD with CoD 2. That was a masterpiece, and if we' think about WW2 games, it still is. And then i played MW series. They were epic, too. But none of them was like BO. Black Ops was the Cod that i'm looking for. Second mp Cod i played was BO2 and it was "meh" for me. you know, if i want to play sci-fi shooter, i'd go and play Titanfall. (And yes, i did play Titanfall)Black Ops has minimal camper count, because it doesn't have ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t high-tech overpowered scorestreaks. Yes, some of them are overpowered, but it's playable.Black Ops does not have too much 12 yo kids who wants to ♥♥♥♥ your mom, because it doesnt have ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t high-tech overpowered scorestreaks and weapons. Oh, same sentence, is it coincidence? Think not.Besides MW2 (i heard it has lots of cheats & hacks and stuff) this is currently the best Multiplayer Call Of Duty you can play without dying of cancer. Also, Black Ops 1's Scenario is my personal favorite. It's classic Call Of Duty "interactive movie" scenario, but it has epic mind♥♥♥♥s and good drama. You'll love it.Worth buying? - I answered that question at TL;DR partStill alive mp? - April 30th, 2016, yes, very active servers.Cheat? - Like in every mp game, but it's avoidable.Singleplayer? -MasterpieceMultiplayer? -♥♥♥♥ing enjoyableDo i need that game to understand BO2? -Not actually, But yes, it'll be better because the reason why second game's scenario is good is first game's scenario.Spoiler: Remember the day you've watched Fight Club. Posted: December 6, 2016
												**Multiplayer online only, haven't played online zombies, only with friends.** Man I missed this game back when it came out on Xbox 360. The community is actually quite active still, and I have yet to see any hackers. Servers are VAC-secured and strictly watched for unsportsman-like conduct. People are very polite, contrary to popular belief. The gameplay style is COMPLETELY different from other shooters like CS:GO, so don't compare them, or else you're just looking like a fool. Word of advice for new players- type "!rules" when you get into a game, or else you could get insta-kicked for using a weapon not allowed or something like that, there's even servers where you're not allowed to move unless you're crouching. I've also heard about people getting VAC bans for using external chat services, so heads up on that.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
ForewordThe first Black Ops in the game series, it is not much different from the rest of the previous games before it. Only the settings and story is different.StoryThe story takes place in the 1960's, playing as Alex Mason, an american operative who is interrogated by unknown captors.They question his previous missions, which take place in various countries. The story heavily focuses on the Cold War Era, and there are several famous people during the Cold War who appear in this game, such as Kennedy and Castro.You can expect all kinds of classic CoD cliché's from previous games in this one, aswell as a twist.Gameplay & GraphicsThe gameplay is very, very much the same as previous Call of Duty titles. Despite this, the multiplayer feels different from previous and newer CoD MP games. It feels more "grittier" with turning, shooting and especially reloading. Not even Black ops 2 MP has this. Overall the animations feel more focused when firing and reloading.The MP of this game is no different from previous games, there are tons of different game modes, a fair amount of maps, lots of weapons and the usual killstreaks. Being a first (This was in 2010 again), you can customize your characters with face paints, and there are quite alot to unlock.Unlike previous MP's, you get "CoD" points each match that you can use to unlock everything with. The game also includes a Zombies mode, having up to 4 co-op players team up against waves upon waves of zombies. The aiming in this feels abit stiff, and sometimes when firing at a zombies head despite aiming perfectly well, the shots may miss.The settings and story in zombies mode is of a supernatural theme, with anything from zombies, ghosts and hounds from hell.The graphics, for a 2010 game, are very good. Back then, it was of course something really well made, graphics wise.Though if you are looking for something amazing for todays standards, you are going to be abit dissapointed.Would I recommend it? If so, why?Yes, I would, but only for the hardcore CoD fans. The MP side is great and what most buyers back in 2010 went for. Today, 2015, I'd say you have to see the story and zombies mode as a bonus when buying the game. The MP side of the game is still very active and has players on servers 24/7, even late night. There are also alot of achievements, both story mode and in zombies. MP there are only 3 achievements.This game is not worth its price tag of 39,99 though. It is 5 years old, and strangely the devs haven't lowered the price. Get it on a sale instead, but even then, you're lucky if you get it for 10.Praise & CriticismI really enjoyed the twist in the story mode.I was impressed by the menu, having not seen this style in any other game.I was not impressed by the DLC map packs, and it is very known these days that not many play the map packs anymore, leaving you with a waste of money, so keep this in mind.You can't review the DLC Map packs individually like other games have on steam. While there are some reviews on them, they are few, and simple, and no doubt done by the devs/friends of the devs, raising the question as to why the reviewing has been disabled for these map packs.Since I can't review the dlc by itself, it'll go hereFIRST CONTACT MAP DLC REVIEWThis review was written months before the main game one, and is mean't as a negative reviewTL:DR: DONT BUY THIS DLC, ITS OVER 4 YEARS OLD AND CANT BE PLAYED ANYMORE DUE TO LIMITED PLAYERBASE.Negative rating explained.One of the steep priced DLC's I've ever bought and regretted. It's surprising how this has so many positive reviews, but they are all funnily enough extremely short. No doubt some fanboys or devs decided to boost this dlc's rep by making such a short review.This dlc comes at full price, 13,99 euro, way to much for something that's over 4 years old by now from this review. A typical marketing strategy from the devs and their publisher, simply leave the price tag at full since launch, with very few sales.This dlc has 5 different maps, nothing more, nothing less. No bonus weapons and such.4 multiplayer maps and 1 zombie mode map.Now I bought this dlc simply for MP maps, not the zombie one, but I saw that as an extra bonus.Today I defently regret this, and this is no way worth its full price. It's a downright scam if you press to buy it for 13,99 euro, there is alot of other stuff you can spend your money on.So why the negative review? Because, all CoD games have this dlc problem pattern. When a new CoD game comes out, the playerbase moves on to the next new thing and abandons (75% of the players atleast) the previous game/s. This leaves a very little, staggering playerbase left, and thus the amount of players who own the dlcs can't find any new games to play these dlc maps. This is why there should never have been dlc map packs in the first place. I admit I fell for the trap. Not once or twice, but thrice, having bought a beautifull map pack in MW3 and BO2. Don't take me wrong, these maps are fun to play on, and are stunningly beautiful. The issue here is not being able to play the dlc anymore. You have to either find friends to start a game and play with, or simply try and hit daytime in hope there just might be a server or two. The chances are extremely low.The Maps.The Maps are detailed, entertaining to play on.Berlin WallA map based on the Berlin Wall, fighting in the snow covered streets of the german capital, the map features a "restricted zone" in the middle among the walls. Running through it will cause automated turrets in towers to kill you. Two parts of the walls have been blown apart and players are able to run between safely from the towers.DiscoveryA map set in the Antartica, an abandoned german base with thin cliff bridges that can be shot or exploded to cause humiliating deaths to players. Perfect for any snow/ice lovers, contains the Southern Lights.KowloonA map set in Hong Kong on building rooftops (You better believe it). Players clash with eachother throughout these large buildings filled with the classic stuff that every major, packed city has (signs, chimneys, antenna's etc). Surprisingly, the buildings still stand after the matches end and a good amount of airstrikes have been used. A good old CoD logic.StadiumA map set at a  hockey stadium in New York, the fights focuses around the outside of the stadium aswell as inside where the ticket booths are. You can't enter into the hockey arena. The map lives up to its name though, the feeling of being at a stadium is well received in this map. Has a large 'Earth' statue fountain in the middle of it.AscensionThe only zombie map in this pack, Ascension takes place in an abandoned Soviet Cosmodome. Instead of Hellhounds, zombified monkeys appear instead, straight from space! The WWII characters make their apperance in this map from the World at War Zombie cast.The maps are great, but for the price, it's simply too steep, counting the age of this dlc aswell. Not only that, but the chances of playing the 4 MP maps with other random players are slim.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												Black Ops is proof that CoD can be a fun series... When it's handled by Treyarch. Overall an improvement over Modern Warfare 2, while also serving as well written and well performed sequel to World at War. The combat is smoother, it (the game) looks slicker and is more colorful, and the singleplayer is probably the tightest in the franchise up to this point. The multiplayer also remains a highlight, being a huge improvement over the previous titles, and I'd argue better than any of the later titles. It's the single-most solid CoD entry, apart from the original and Modern Warfare. The few cons, though, primarily rest in the multiplayer. Although it may be the best laid out version of the famous game mode, there are some balancing issues in terms of some weapons; namely the FAMAS. Now, for the most part, if a weapon is over-powered, then use it. The issue with it is the whole leveling up system, which means that newer players either rely on luck, the also powerful MP5K, or try to find maps where there aren't too many FAMAS players. In addition, the CoD Points system is a great idea, but could have been better implemented. For example, what's the point of obtaining points when all of the weapons are still locked by level requirements? You might earn a  lot of CoD Points, but they're useless if you want a weapon you need several more levels to unlock with. EIther leveleing should open up more than one thing to buy, thus giving you more options to spend your money on at a time in the early and later games (Note that mid game more things do become unlocked at a stime, but this usually centers around different logo layers or reticules, all of which are cosmetic features). Note that when you do buy a weapon, you have all of the attachements unlocked. You just need to spend CoD Points on them. That makes sense, but why only the attachments? This mode could have worked better, but still does some things right. Overall, the redundancy of parts of the point system can still be overlooked. Ultimately, we're still looking at one of CoD's more solid modern gen entries, and I'd suggest picking it up. Good servers can be difficult to find (There's a ton of so-called "Tactical Crouch Servers," and other servers ban game elements outright), but with or without, the singleplayer and the Co-Op Zombies mode are also very fun to play. (NOTES: Aside from the PC, I've also played this game far more extensively on the PS3 and Nintendo Wii, totalling more than a hundred or more hours)

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												First of all, i would like to say that this review is pretty much entirely for historical purposes, since the multiplayer is dead.Black Ops 1 is a fairly good game. It pretty much kept the same formula as the one in MW2, but fixed all the major complaints.Balance fixesLike, noob tubes (grenade launchers), which could deal a max of 155 damage. They were extremely overpowered even back in COD4 and there were even perks that would increase the damage to explosives by 25%. In MW2 in fact, it was increased to 40%.What made that matter worse in MW2, is that you could replenish your ammo for those launchers, with Scavenger and One Man's Army. Well, the good news is that Scavenger doesn't replenish explosives anymore, and One Man's Army was removed. The explosives damage increase perk was removed as well. The damage was still the same - 155 (stayed like that since COD4), but they also returned a perk that should decrease the incoming explosive damage by 35% (actually it's 10% increase compared to COD4/COD5).Another big problem of MW2 was the perk commando, which would increase the knife range from 128 to 176. That perk was removed as well.Another issue was the nuke - 25 kill killsteak that would end the game. The problem with that is that kills with your killstreaks would count too. You could go 7-11-25 for your build, and easily reach a nuke. In BO1, not only they removed the nuke, but they also made a rule - you can only increase your killstreak by killing with your gun. That solved the problem of snowballing.That said, both knife and grenade launchers are very powerful in this game. In later games like BO2 - knife would be a 2 hit kill, and in MW3 - noob tube damage would be reduced to 110, while in BO2 to 130. In BO3 grenade launchers are completely removed.Comparison to other CODsOther than that, it is pretty much identical to MW2. The weapons are different, the maps are different, but other wise, all the mechanics of the game are more of the same.There are of course a few new things here and there. For example, they implemented a different leveling system. Before, you level up, you get your gear. In Black Ops 1, you get money for leveling up, which you can spend on weapons, attachments, perks, killstreaks and so on. There are a few level restriction for some gear, but the main point is that you can pretty much get the gear you like from the get go. They also added wager matches. You wage your money over there and you will play one of the 4 modes featured - gun game, stick and stones, sharpshooter and one in the chamber.All of them are very fun modes. There are altogether 6 players, but only the top 3 will get any rewards. The game kind of forces you to play those modes if you want to unlock everything.Another new thing was the theater mode - ability to rewatch and record your previous matches. It made its debut in BO1, and that feature continued appearing in all Black Ops games.Finally, unlike other CODs, all Black Ops games feature bot matches, so i guess you can still give it a go if you are interested in that sort of play.PC PortThe port for pc wasn't all that good when it was released. In fact, it's because of that BO1 had a pretty short lifespan on PC compared to other CODs.There were netcode and performance issues, and it took like a year till all of those were fixed.The game features dedicated servers, but no custom ones are allowed. They are rent-able, but only allow 12-18 players. I actually don't mind that. I really hate 64 player COD4/COD5 lobbies - they were completely unbalanced. Sometimes, giving too much power to the gamers is bad.Campaign and ZombiesAs for the campaign, it's your typical linear shooter. I wouldn't really blame them for it, since that's the way COD has been since the very first game.The game is set in the Cold War era, and even features a cameo from World at War. Basically, they just took a lot of Cold War events and just put their characters in there. The story got a lot of praise as well, and truly, you got to give them credit for that.As for zombies, there are 2 maps - Five and Kino Der Toten. 4 more come as DLC. The mode practically didn't change since World at War. It's basically a wave based survival game. Tons of fun and you can still play it since it doesn't really on online play that much - just find 3 friends and you are on.ConclusionOverall, it's a pretty good game. More of the same, but unlike the CODs to come, this one actually had balanced spawns. Personally, i think this was the time when COD started going downhill.It had a rocky start when it was released on pc, and it never really recovered, Also, just like all CODs, the numbers really start to perish when the new one comes out, so i can only recommend it to you for its zombies. Single player is okey, but not enough to sell you the game. You might want to buy the DLC zombie map packs though.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												This is without a doubt my favorite first person shooter ever made. But why?Campaign - Takes you through a fun adventure during the Cold War. Fun gameplay (Kowloon potentially the best CoD mission ever), great characters (Jason Hudson as portrayed by Ed Harris) and interesting story with a nice twist. Zombies - This is just a simply incredible gamemode. It has such an addicting factor to get to a higher round, but is also plagued with secrets and a lot to do within each map keeping it mostly fresh and it goes on and on. The Rezurrection also brought the old World at War maps back, which includes my personal favorite map, Der Riese. This rendition of Zombies was also improved from its predecessor, World at War. Although you cannot create your own maps this time, sadly, it provides for an excellent experience. All maps are good and worth playing and it introduces more legendary maps like Ascension and Moon to add to the collection. Multiplayer - The great thing about this is that its skill based, and encapsulates all methods of playstyle. Maps are a variety of sizes, and each map is its own unique adventure and a change of pace from the last. As much as I'm not a big fan of smaller maps that much, this game has 2-3 which make it a nice change of pace. Guns are balanced, and all do relativley the same thing so that you don't lose a fight simply because of circumstance. Recoil is in the guns, and many battles take place at medium - long range so you need to be good with the gun to get a kill. It moves at just the right speed; you can be in a fight mostly whenever you want but can also pursure flanking and you won't be in a clusterf**k all the time. WMD is also probably the best multiplayer map ever; representative of all playstyles, isn't too small and isn't too big. It also has CoD Points, the best the series has done yet from an unlocking perspective. It's the slow of the fast paced gameplay, exactly what I like. This game is just excellent. DLC's are just as great with maps such as Zoo, Hotel, Discovery and Hazard (remake of Cliffside from World at War). Bonus: An entire twin stick shooter game is within this game, known as Dead Ops Arcade. This is an absurd amount of fun, and really adds on to the package of this game. Also included is the text based game Zork, which can provide a great past time. In addition, the hidden intel and computer that lets you logon to characters profiles provides for great backstory and nice information for what happend before, during and after and insight into each character.This is just the best FPS ever. Get it.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Call of Duty: Black Ops emerges across all the doubts surrounding the Activision/Infinity Ward company that took place back in March 2010, in which many speculated about an inevitable fall from grace for the Call of Duty franchise. Beside that the hard work behind the doors at Treyarch proved that they could bring the franchise to bigger and better heights, although the risk of stepping away from the path, particularly in terms of storytelling, the story still has plenty of the blockbuster elements that the franchise is known for, and manages a much more intelligent light since it's not just the typical action for action's sake type of game. Call of Duty: Black Ops is a first-person shooter with stealth and tactical play aspect that puts players in the role of a shadow soldier, Alex Mason, fighting in a variety of historically representative fictional Black Ops missions of the Cold War era. The story has a well-written narrative and the main character has more vocal presence than any previous Call of Duty. It's also clear a good balance between set piece moments as well, the bigger cinematic approach and the addition of a few cutscenes, rather than having dialogue throughout loading screens manage to improve the gaming experience, beside that the graphics are pretty decent.The campaign mode is roughly a 7-8 hours thrill, and although the campaign doesn't support co-op play, there is the zombie mode which does, even though fighting off the walking dead can be fun alone, it's way better with up to four players.Apart from the singleplayer, the multiplayer component had its fair share of alterations. The most evident is the new currency upgrade system, this new method allows players to earn "COD" points in addition to experience points during matches, which gives players a level field by having all perks and attachments available for purchase at the start. Also, once you've unlocked the appropriate categories through ranking up, you can acquire any kill streak reward you wish or invest in an insane amount of customization options.There is also a new Combat Training simulator, allowing practice in Free-For-All or Team Deathmatch modes against AI opponents. If that wasn't enough, Treyarch even included an in-depth Combat Record to give a detailed look at how your multiplayer stats break down. It includes everything from kill/death ratio graphs, individual weapon stats, to heat maps that show the main spots of activity.Overall, the campaign is thrilling from beginning to end, the competitive multiplayer is as addictive as ever, and there are plenty of zombies to be slaughtered for all the co-op players. 75/100

content:
Posted: April 5
												This is by far, the best Black Ops IMHO. I originally played this on the PS3 and made a lot of cool friends that I stayed friends with for many years, until I moved on to PC. Anyway, I loved it so much I got it again and all the DLC on Steam so I can play it at 1080p at true 60fps with no frame drops like there was on the PS3 when you took out at mob of zombies with the Thunder Gun or during an Insta-kill at any round.The great thing about this map is the re-playability. I like seeing players in the lobby when I want to play. I wish people would get the DLC because all the DLC is great and so much fun. Ascension is where PhD Flopper was first introduced...that has to be the easiest map of all the DLC. Call of the Dead was my absolute favorite. It too has PhD Flopper but it was the first map to have a lingering Boss...Georgy Romero. I met a lot of cool friends with that map as well. I think that map is what got me hooked on Zombies and when I became better at them.A tough map but still a lot of fun was Shagri-La. I still remember waiting until the very stroke of midnight in the US to download the DLC to my PS3. Those were the days. I know this review is coming in late...almost a decade after its release but like all things in expectation, it was like Christmas in November back then. By the way, before playing Shangri-La, I suggest playing Five a lot if you feel Shangri-La is hard or if you keep dying a lot. In fact, before the map came out, we found out months ahead that there would be tight pathways, so we practived with Five for a few months before the release...we were randked in the top 1/10 of 1% in the world for the first week it was out. I still have a screenshot of that somewhere from a Happauge PVR. Yep...ancient technology.I don't want to do through the list of the DLC maps but the other maps are great. I highly recommend this game and all the DLC for it. I can see this game being a long-living staple in the FPS Zombie community,

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Call of Duty gets a ton of hate for their franchise from more intellectual gamers.It's an undeniable truth - but this game in particular, and the ones before it, are where it was good. If you're basing your opinion off this game just because you played Black Ops II or Ghosts, you're not going to have a fantastic time. I find that the Nazi Zombies gameplay was greatly done. It was not over the top and it used original game elements from World at War, sticking to the original style and going classic, while at the same time adding lots of necessary and new features.The map packs are overpriced in people's opinions. I did not have Black Ops on Steam when it came out - I bought it here a couple months ago so I could enjoy it all over again. If I had to estimate, I'd say I clocked about 3,000 hours on the console version? (Dirty me!) It was fantastic. Owning all of the map packs the day they came out, I was addicted to Zombies. However, I did not enjoy the currency system applied on the multiplayer. Opinions are opinions, it was cool, but grew old quickly trying to farm so much XP.Overall - 8/10The multiplayer flaws are arguable. I cannot ignore them, so I will have to deduct a few points off as multiplayer is a large part of the game. However, Zombies was a very enjoyable and addictive experience that promised a unique experience, especially when you played with friends on a co-op game.

												To me Call of Duty: Black ops was the last CoD that was amazing and here is the reason why. The campaign I thought was excellent with likable characters. great storyline, and the era it takes place in. content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												i preordered this game back in 2010. after that i swore i'd never purchase another game sight unseen and i have kept my word on that. this one is where they really blew it. i feel sorry for anybody who would buy this game in 2014. if you have a choice between this and world at war, choose waw because it was the last good game in the series, the last to offer an actual modding system. they removed that from the game in black ops and never looked back. they claimed from the start that they would provide mod tools but their idea of mod tools this time turned out to be nothing basically, a few tweaks for the multiplayer, no graphics mods, no new maps whatsoever because they wanted to sell their dlc instead of continuing to uphold their good reputation so they flushed mod tools down the toilet with this one game. so if the zombie game is what you're after, this game will give you a total of about ten laggy maps for an extra sixty dollars, four of which came from world at war and they run flawlessly in waw yet lag in black ops the allegedly superior black ops engine, wonder why that is. also in world at war there are hundreds of maps already made for nazi zombies that are entirely free for everyone and the game is actually playable and runs flawlessly. the choice is yours. if you want single player action, this game is also a bad choice because the single player campaign is mostly like watching a movie as i recall. anyway, even with the current sale it's only half what it cost at launch four years ago. so not worth it. sooooooooo not worth it. you'll be sorry if you fall for it...

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Call of Duty®: Black OpsViktor Reznov's eight steps to escape the prison of Vorkuta:"Every journey begins with a single step. This is Step One!" -- ReznovStep 1: Secure the Keys - Overpower the guard and get the keys.Step 2: Ascend from Darkness - Use the elevator to get to ground level.Step 3: Rain Fire - Use the slingshot to destroy the three guard towers.Step 4: Unleash the Horde - Use the prison broadcast system to rally the prisoners.Step 5: Skewer the Winged Beast - Take down the helicopter with the KS-23 harpoon.Step 6: Wield the Fist of Iron - Acquire a mini-gun from the vault with the help of Reznov.Step 7: Raise Hell - Storm the prison guards and fight your way down the road.Step 8: Freedom - Use the motorcycles in the garage to escape the prison.Do these steps sound familiar? Yes...it's the same steps used in Call of Duty®: Black Ops II Zombies - OriginsSounds exciting? Well, it might give you enough reason to buy this game (as well as Call of Duty®: Black Ops II). The campaign story line is epic and the plot won’t let you down. The characters are strong, well-crafted and dramatic moments give the story some intrigue and a tone of uncertainty allowing your missions to cover a vast diverseness of gameplay and geographics. Up until now I believe this game's campaign story is one of the best in the series.Call of Duty®: Black Ops offers an online Multiplayer mode where you can earn experience points while leveling up, unlocking custom class slots, weapons, perks, killstreak bonuses, emblems, reticles and more...And for those who want some more bang for buck, Black Ops offers a popular four-player cooperative Zombie mode. You'll fight to stay alive against endless waves of undead lusus naturae. It's a bold and bizarre endeavor, but with characters and personalities to entertain you through some bloodcurdling situations.Nevertheless, the game at its core is terrific and in my opinion Call of Duty®: Black Ops (and its successor) has stood the test of time.

Posted: May 31, 2016
												I play only single player and co op.The game is pretty much dead only servers with Nuketown are left and some S&D.The single player is amaizing as any CoD single player it's like a movie linear with a lot of cut scenes but it's an eye candy.Co op Zombies are epic if you have friends to play with that are good. Otherwise you will get sick from playing te first parts of the maps and then die. There are no public matches on zombies.Co op Multiplayer is only TDM and FFA against bots. It has different leveling than the Multiplayer part of the game. The dificulty of the bots only makes their aim faster and at some point it feels like a normal MW3 game (full of cheaters with aim bot) however if you play with your friends against a horde of bots it is ridiculously fun.I am giving thumbs up because it has dedicated servers! But if I have to rate it I would give it 6/10 because the co op part apart from the zombies is very limited.However this is probably the only actually good Call of duty game.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												This is my favorite call of duty of all time, and is probably top 10 for best games I've ever played. This game is still good to THIS day and can still be enjoyable. I've broken my review into each part of the game.CAMPAIGN-This campaign was pretty good, not only from an action/gameplay stand point, but the story in this game is really good and has good twist and keeps you interested. The length is pretty decent and is very enjoyable.Multiplayer-My favorite COD multiplayer out there. Many people worry about hackers, but there aren't many hackers on multiplayer on the PC version surprisenly, you choose servers from a list of servers and it's done pretty well, it stills holds up from 6 years ago.Zombies-The best gamemode ever made in COD, I know hundreds of people who only play this game for the zombies, and it's reasonable, this gamemode is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing and is best played with friends, I don't really like this game when playing solo, I don't feel it's as enjoyable.Overall-This game still holds up everything it was when released 6 years ago and is worth the 40$ it cost.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												This is arguably the best call of duty to date. It depends wether or not you are a Treyarch fan or Infinity Ward fan. Most fans of Call Of Duty say Modern Warfare is the best one, but I always was more keen on Treyarchs version of COD. Dont get me wrong, I know that COD MW innovated alot and changed the multiplayer to the better and that their campaign were a thrill. I also know that COD MW also changed the genre, but when it comes to the best of the best I would say that this game is the best... of the best. The campaign is special and unique. I havent seen anyone else do the COD campaign like that. It got me interested from begining to end as it isnt just a war story about a soldier (as most call of duty games) but it also involves conspiracy theories, phsyciatric challenges and monkeys. Okey, the last one is not as important, but I am serious about the other things and really believe that this is the best campaign. Maybe that has to do with the setting. I fell in love with the cold war (not as in I liked the cold war, but more as in I like the story behind it). The only COD game that isnt modern/futuristic or about the second world war. I kinda hope it stays that way, because they did a good job and I dont really think they could make it better. I have heard rumors about Sledgehammer making a game set during the cold war and I hope its false. Would be nice to make a game that is set in the past, but make it about something else. Give us something new (and as most cod players mean with something new, give us more content dont change up the mechanics). To get back on track, the campaign is something that you have to try out for your self. The multiplayer was also pretty great. It stayed fast paced with memorable maps, nice weapon balancing and fun game modes. The perks werent too bad either, although I will admit that "second chance" perk was a bad one. Luckily most servers on PC has banned that perk. Killstreaks return and all of them serve a purpose. There is more focus on party modes and that is always fun. I really enjoy what they did with cod points. No, Im not talking about the latest version of cod points where you actually have to spend money on it. Im talking about the in-game currency that you use to unlock camoes, weapons, attatchements and of course face paint. You could play wager matches and gamble your money to maybe win more money. Those matches were intense, but no other COD game has tried to replicate it. It is a Black Ops only experience.While the multiplayer and campaign were exeptional in COD MW, the game still lacked a memorable and fun coop mode. Well, COD BO steps up their game with continuing on COD Zombies. The problem with COD BO2 and COD BO3 is that the maps are made for zombie fans. You might think that im weird for complaining about them making maps for the zombie fans, but what I mean is that the maps in those games were not casual friendly. I enjoyed the maps in those games, even my favourite zombie maps comes from those games, but I am a COD Zombies fan. I have an interest in it and I am patient enough to learn the maps. However, anyone who isnt like me will have a problem figuring out what is going on and what to do. The last maps are all about objectives. The steps you have to take just to pack-a-punch in those games are completely bonkers (yes I used the word bonkers to describe it). Playing public on those maps are so hard. You just have to hope that you meet a player that is also a zombie fan. For a casual game like COD, the maps in BO2 and BO3 were so so amazingly not casual that people just stuck to multiplayer and then got bored. I understand why they would complain too. COD is a 3 for 1 deal. You get multiplayer, campaign and coop. When you only get multiplayer and campaign, you can feel a little bit scammed. Like it wasnt worth the money. In this game they manage to keep the maps casual while also adding easter eggs, story and tricks for the Zombie fans. So a zombie expert could have just as much fun as a casual player. All in all, the game is good and I completely recommend it. If you like Call Of Duty, then you wont be dissapointed. Buy this game. The only complaint about the pricing is the DLCs. They can be expenisve, so just buy them on sale. There are no seasonpass on PC so make sure that you wait for the right time to buy them all. The DLCs is mainly for people who are interested in zombies. You dont need it either. You still got 3 fun zombie maps without it. At last, I do know it says that I have 3 hours on this game, but I played it a lot on console before switching to PC. I bought it again on steam because I just had to have this masterpiece in my steam library. Either way, I doubt that you will actually read all of this so Im basically talking to myself at this point. Just buy it and try it. You wont regret if you are a fan of the series.Edit: I have now many more hours into this game since I decided to revisit the game. I can tell you that I still stand by everything I have said in this review and it makes me recommend it even more.

												The single player campiagn is based on the cold war era and a little bit on the second world war. based on the reaction of nuclear warfare . Great for Zombie Veterans for a comeback. Kino der toten , Moon , Shangrila , Call of the Dead Multiplayer pros and cons of Black ops.  Pros - Dedicated severs.- Interesting story which links to world at war - Nuketown map- Return of world at war zombie maps- Huge variety of weapons and attachments in both single and multi  Cons- Some Maps are to big and uneven for TDM- Unpopulated severs- Overpowered weapons

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Call of Duty: Black Ops was released in 2010. It can be played in single player mode as well as Multiplayer Mode and Zombies: Multiplayer Mode, both of which are immensely fun. Having played it to 100% completion on the PS3 already, I can't give it any higher praise. Only games that I think are fantastic do I bother putting in the kind of effort to achieve 100%. You play as Alex Mason, a soldier who is being held and interrogated, as you progress through various black ops Mason went on over several years. I can't go into more detail without spoilers, so I will leave it at that.Call of Duty: Black Ops, plays the same way previous titles in the Call of Duty franchise, so if you like that style, Black Ops won't disappoint. Multiplayer is actually rather fun with Black Ops, as is Zombies Mode, where you can play on several Maps and must survive waves of zombies with a team of other players. Call of Duty: Black Ops has went on to be successful enough to spawn 2 sequels, which I have not yet had the chance to play, but that does speak volumes of how popular the game was and still is. If you like first person action/shooters, Black Ops is a must play.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2010
												You'd think they'd test it with the latest hardware before shipping it.  Or maybe just test it at all.  I am still having problems with graphics hitching, which Treyarch has (allegedly) attributed to problems with the 400 series graphics cards from nVidia.  Three patches post release, and they still haven't addressed the problem.  Also, being unable to directly connect to a server that you've paid for because the server browser doesn't work correctly and they seem to have left the \connect and \reconnect commands out of the console... just make this game yet another cluster♥♥♥♥ in a line of cluster♥♥♥♥s.  If it wasn't for the fact that Treyarch was riding the wave of a successful franchise, or riding the wave of other franchises in general (such as James Bond), they wouldn't be a successful development house at all.I will reserve judgement on the game itself until I can actually play it.  Until then, I can only comment on its technical shortcomings.

Posted: July 20, 2014
												Definitely a good game, it's kinda outdated now that Ghosts is out and Advanced Warfare will be coming out soon (as of now).I really enjoyed playing this game back in 2011/12 on my PS3 so I thought that it'd be a good idea to have some fun on the PC version to see what's different, not much has changed but still we get to actually use chat now except no matchmaking lobbies on multiplayer (which is annoying when you want to play with your friends) unlike on the XBox 360, PS3 and Wii versions.If you're really into the Vietnam and Cold Wars, this could be an ideal game for you but if you're not into Call of Duty, I don't blame you because I prefer the older ones myself. Call of Duty 4 up to Modern Warfare 3 was pretty much the bomb at the time.However the only thing I would recommend you do if you plan on buying this game is to buy a cheaper steam key on eBay or something or wait until the game becomes at least half-price (like I did, as I bought the game during the 2014 summer sale) as the game isn't worth as much as £30, despite that the game is now almost 4 years old already.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Oh man, I really don't want to do this, but sadly I must give Black Ops a negative review.  Mind you I like this game.  As a game it's top notch and worth playing.  However I'm quite annoyed at the actual PC version of this game. The problems stem from the fact that there's NO niceties and at least one VERY big flaw.   First the opening interface is HORRIBLE on PC.  You literally MUST have a keyboard for the game to work.  Even a mouse won't allow you to use the menu efficently.  So trying to play this game with just a controller  is a horrible experience.  In addition even though controllers work in game, they don't work well.   You can get all the functionality you expect in game, but on the pause menu the controller only works with the pause button.   You can't select anything with out a mouse or keyboard.  Even when the controller works in game, it doesn't work out of game, so the main menu still doesn't work, and will require a keyboard and a mouse if you are ever use big picture mode. That isn't a big problem, however the interface all over feels like a interface from 2005, even in a 2010 game this is outdated, but again I could live with this. However there's two major issues I have.  First the game does try to cloud save something but does a horrible job of it (nothing is stored in the cloud) but the worse problem is if you somehow run out of memory as you play the game (not impossible) the game will actually delete your save data.   I ended up losing my entire progress because of this when nearing the end of the game, a second time. I mean seriously? I had a save game that was quite far, and then there was a dialog telling me the game was out of memory, and when I quit to fix the problem, my save game was wiped.     Black Ops was one of the best Call of Duty games in years, but I'd recommend a console copy if you want to play it now for the single player.  The PC version is ok, but definitely showing it's age.   Of course if you want mouse and keyboard you'll have to play on the PC, but that'd be the only reason I'd recommend playing this game, It's not a bad game, but damn it, the game should be far better than these problems.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												Treyarch can pat themselves on their backs for creating such an amazing game. With their pass game history of mediocre games (CoD 3 and CoD WAW). They have set the bar high with Black Ops. Black Ops comes out on top of MW2 with vast improvements and most importantly, dedicated servers for multi-player. As well, the online RPG leveling system allows players to purchase which perks they like instead of having to work through a pre-determined list of perks. Beautiful multi-player maps, balanced guns, and crisp controls make the multi-player experience unforgettable. The single player campaign is roughly 7-8 hours of story-compelling, non-stop action. A game that can deliver a good story while making the characters feel believable and alive is a rare occasion. If you are a CoD fan, this is a must purchase. If you like FPS, but dislike CoD games. This is still a MUST purchase.

If you're still questioning my credibility I have the server list here[www.gametracker.com] which is more detailed. The only legit enjoyment out of this game is playing the Campaign, Zombies mode, and the very few standard Team Deathmatch servers. Another thing, DO NOT BUY MAP PACKS. It's worthless back then, but with the exception of exclusive zombie maps. If you're planning to buy this, save it for a console copy as some still play the game through there as of 2016.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Playing Black Ops on veteran difficulty, you will......get blindsided by an enemy's melee attack while AI partners stand around oblivious to his presence...not use dual-wield weapons, for they are useless...get your aim thrown off by an explosion rattling the screen while your enemies remain unaffected...encounter NPC's frozen in place and restart your game...throw a grenade through what you thought was a hole, only to realize it was an invisible wall before blowing yourself up...spend at least two hours in those godforsaken corridors on Executive Orders(I mean seriously, Treyarch still can't balance a difficulty curve to save their lives. I looked it up - it is unanimously agreed upon as the hardest part in the game. The third mission. Second hardest part? Fourth mission. High fives all around the Treyarch offices, good work team)...still get killed by grenade spamming, because Treyarch never read any of the World at War reviews...wish Treyarch was sober when they placed the checkpoints...leap into the air like a mad banshee after sprinting to cover and trying to go prone, because Treyarch thought that mapping the sprint jump to the prone button was smart durrrrrrrr...get killed by stray bullets during CUTSCENES, seriously I can't even make that up...realize that unlike the last game, you can no longer restart a checkpoint from the ESC menu. "Why?" you may ask. "Because ♥♥♥♥ you," Treyarch replies.--------------------------------------------Beginner's Guide to Getting a Review Negged by Everybody on Steam.Step 1: Write a negative review about a Call of Duty game.Step 2: Don't even mention zombies or the multiplayer. ♥♥♥♥ multiplayer.Step 3: Get negged.--------------------------------------------

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												READ THIS REVIEW. IT IS WORTH YOUR TIME! (Also, spoilers ahead.)---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This game is one of the best CoDs that I've ever played in a long time. From Storyline, to Maps, to Multiplayer, and to Zombies, this game truly has it all.Let's start off with the storyline: It is too long to cover in one go so I will sum it up breifly. You play as a CIA Operative known as Alex Mason. Captured by the (Russians or Germans, I forgot) you are put in a prison/holding area. You manage to escape the area but get recaptured. You are brainwashed to kill JFK but the brainwashing then gets changed to kill three of your biggest opposers. Cold War happens and then the story continues like normal. You kill the three people and save JFK and retire from then on.Now to the Multiplayer: There's a lot to say about the multiplayer. To sum it up: Maps-Good Guns-Good Gamemodes-GoodFinally to the Zombies: Storyline-wise, I can't give it because it is too complicated and long, but if you would like to learn about the whole zombies storyline (So Far), copy and paste this link to your browser: http://callofduty.wikia.com/wiki/Zombies_(mode)/StoryBut I give the same opinion to the multiplayer segment. Good maps, Good guns, Good story, and really funny characters.Thanks for taking the time to read over my review, and in short, this game is worth the $40.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Being a Call of Duty player since MW2 I was very impressed with the depth of the plot in the single player campaign for Call of Duty: Black Ops. It's a story I would play over multiple times. The story obviously revolves around the Cold War and U.S. Special Forces who try to prevent mass conflict by confining it to small targeting ops and raids. The story leads you through several moments in U.S. Cold War history like Vietnam, Cuba, and Russia. If you are a fan of the Call of Duty series then this would be a good buy for you.

Zombies is the gamemode that usually gets the most attention, however It's not the only good part about the game. Multiplayer on the PC offers a bunch of different game modes separate from the main three the game seems to originally offer, these allow variety and adds replay value to get you coming back for more. Similar to the earlier Call of Duty games the campaign is fantastic, It's so enjoyable in fact that you may find yourself replaying it numerous times. In the end Black Ops 1 is a great game and a great buy.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												I have played this game so much on EVERY console, even including the Nintendo Wii. This is possibly one of my favorite Call of Duty games alongside MW3, and I still enjoy playing it today. Yes, the multiplayer may have quite a bit of cheaters, but I have a lot of good memories on this game dating back to its release date. I have never dedicated so much time to a Call of Duty game before and it just makes me sad to see what Call of Duty is turning into now. Advanced Warfare looks like complete crap to me and I wish they would come up with something unique and original to give me the same experience that I had on the older games like this. Call of Duty: Ghosts already took it too far with the Aliens, and Advanced Warfare is going to take it even farther. I am going to wait for Treyarch's next realease and see what they do. If their next realease is horrible, then I am calling it an end to Call of Duty. It had it's time but it looks like it's drifting away.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												The most enjoyable multiplayer CoD for me, and I've played everything from BO1 onwards. BO1 has real dedics (MW3 had those too!), so crap like lag-comp or hacks are non-issue here (as long as the admins are ok, but you can always play on another dedic, which isn't exactly the case with newer lobby-only CoDs). Maps are fine, weapons are fine, killstreaks are probably fine. I simply have fun playing it.HOWEVER! Beware, because the game is quite badly optimized. I couldn't play it for years before I got 270x (which isn't exactly the top GPU, but not the cheapest either). On my old radeon 6850 (and even older nvidias I had) the game was simply unplayable. Insane FPS drops and a bonus mouse lag which made your sensitivity +- random. Not something you'd enjoy in a competitive FPS. Weird, considering BO2 never had any trouble on my previous hardware.

content:
Posted: February 17
Call of Duty Black Ops Campaign ReviewCall of Duty Black Ops is when the series starts turning its focus and intentions in a very different direction. While Black Ops is the 7th Call of Duty game it is the 5th chronologically, which why I chose play it after World At War instead of jumping to Modern Warfare. Now I know that canon wise it really doesn’t matter, but I just like to see how the technology evolves in terms of guns and warfare. In Call of Duty: Black Ops gone are the days of a Call of Duty game feeling like an actual war video game. Granted you are partaking in the Vietnam war, but it feels less authentic than the other Call of Duty’s in a different way. You don’t “Hold the Line” or “Hold out for reinforcements” You don’t partake in actual war strategy. Now the other Call of Duty games weren't’ strategic war shooters, but while the strategies were preselected for you, I felt that it was interesting to partake in them. Making sure you popped smoke grenades or that you drove your tank close to the enemies because your tank was not powerful from long range. Now does that make Call of Duty Black Ops a bad game? No, absolutely not, but it does make it quite a different experience than well pretty much any Call of Duty before Modern Warfare 2. And it’s an experience that is action-filled and thrilling to partake in. It’s set-pieces are well designed and from an artistic view beautifully rendered. Call of Duty’s artists are definitely a talented bunch. Whether it be Infinity Ward, Treyarch, or Sledgehammer you can never really complain that they aren’t good-looking games. So how does the game hold up an action-movie like experience? Surprisingly well it turns out. Call of Duty picks up it’s influence from Half-Life or even Uncharted in the sense that you are always pretty much in control of the action, even in the bombastic set pieces. While these set pieces aren’t particularly difficult they are fun to play. Most of Black Ops’ campaign is fun to play while never really having a dull moment or heavy repetition, besides the fact that you are shooting all the time. I guess about the only negative thing I could level at the campaign is that it’s frustratingly short and ends a bit too quickly. I finished it’s campaign in about 4 and a half hours. Pretty much the same length of almost every COD campaign after the first Modern Warfare. Thematically COD is as strong as ever. The graphics while using the same engine are still improved. The environments and effects still hold up even in 2017, while it’s obviously no match for its contemporaries it’s still a good looking game. The soundtrack in the game is pretty good, while having some songs that, while are always used in the Vietnam setting, are great to listen to all the same. The voice cast is pretty darn impressive and seems to be the most extensively Hollywood COD ever. I mean you have Ed Harris, Sam Worthington, Ice Cube, and even Gary Oldman. I don’t think I’ve seen this much recognizable stars in a COD game before. The great thing is that they are good to great. Ice Cube and Ed Harris are easily the weakest, but through no fault of their own as they are only playing their type. Gary Oldman as always just disappears behind a role even in a video game. He’s easily the strongest. The most surprising however is Sam Worthington who definitely gives it his all in his performance. While he mostly is just sitting in a chair the whole time, anytime he has to show a bit of emotion he does it really well. I could feel his confusion, frustration, and pain of his character.Black Ops is definitely different from the World War 2 based shooters and follows after it’s modern brethren, but it’s still an entertaining action romp through the 60’s with all the bells and whistles  one expects in a COD campaign by now. Recommended if on sale.   Used in a Windows 10 Computer, with a GTX 970, and an i7 3820.    Game ran well, with no hiccups or CTDs whatsoever.    Collected all intel and gathered as many achievements as I could. As always don’t expect to 100% this game unless you are ready to fight through tedium and immense frustration. This is pretty much par for the course for any COD game.
